subsection.title: Sets of Numbers
subsection.p: Before introducing functions, we'll need a brief summary of set theory and some of the associated vocabulary and notations we use in the text. We begin with a definition.
A set is a collection of objects which are called the elements of the set.
For example, the collection of letters that make up the word coyote is a set. Here are three ways to describe sets:

li.p: The Verbal Method: Use a sentence to define the set.
The Roster Method: Begin with a left brace ' \{', list each element of the set once, end with a right brace ` \}'.
The Set-Builder Method: A combination of the verbal and roster methods using a mathemaical expression to describe the set.
For example, let S be the set described verbally as: The set of letters that make up the word coyote.

A roster description of S would be \{c,o,y,t,e\}. Note that we listed 'o' only once, even though it appears twice in coyote. The order of the elements doesn't matter, so \{t,e,y,o,c\} also is a roster description of S.
Now consider the set, T of integers \{1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9\}
A set-builder description of T is: \{x \; | \; x is a positive integer with x /lt 10 \}. The way to read this is: The set of positive integers x such that x is less than 10.

subsection.p: In each of the above cases, we may use the familiar equals sign '=' and write S = \{c,o,t,e,y\} or T = \{x \; | \; x is a positive integer with x \lt 10 \}. Clearly t is in S and 3 is not in S. Here are several famous sets of numbers.

li.p: The Empty Set: \emptyset = \{ \}. This is the set with no elements. Like the number 0, it plays a vital role in mathematics.
The Natural Numbers: \mathbb{N} = {1, 2, 3, \dots } The three periods in a row here indicate that the natural numbers contain 1, 2, 3, and so forth.

The Rational Numbers: \mathbb{Q} = \{\frac{a}{b}\; |\; a \mbox{ and } b \mbox{ are integers with } b \neq 0\}. Rational numbers are the ratios of integers (provided the denominator is not zero!). It turns out that another way to describe the rational numbers is:

p.m: \mathbb{Q} = \{x \; | \; x \mbox{ is a real number that has a repeating or terminating decimal representation}\}.

li.p: The Real Numbers: \mathbb{R} = \{ x \; | \; x \mbox{ is a decimal number}\}.
The Irrational Numbers: \mathbb{P} = \{ x \; | \; x \mbox{ is a non-rational real number }\}. Said another way, an irrational number is a decimal that is not a repeating decimal.

subsection.p: It is important to note that every natural number is an integer. Each integer is a rational number (taking b = 1 in the above definition for \mathbb{Q} produces integers) and the rational numbers are all real numbers, since they possess decimal representations. For the most part, we will focus on sets whose elements come from the real numbers \mathbb{R}.

subsection.title: Interval Notation
subsection.p: Interval notation is a shorthand way of describing an interval. For example, for real numbers a and b, (a,b) is interval notation for the set of all real numbers x bigger than a and less than b. The table given below displays interval notation for different kinds of intervals.

sidebyside.p: Region on the Real Number Line

aside.p: Square brackets [ or ] indicate that an endpoint is included in the interval; round parentheses ( or ) indicate that an endpoint is not included.

assemblage.title: WeBWorK: Entering Infinity and Inequalities
assemblage.p:
Type
inf for \infty and -inf for -\infty
>= for \geq and <= for \leq

subsection.p: Note that we could write the inequality 1 < x < 3 as 3 > x > 1 and still have the same set. An easy way to remember which inequality symbol to use is that the smaller (pointy) end of the inequality sign points to the smaller number and conversely the wide end is next to the larger value.

sidebyside.p: Region on the Real Number Line

subsection.p: We will need to combine sets. Intersection and union are two basic ways to combine sets. We define both of these concepts below.

Suppose A and B are two sets.
The intersection of A and B contains the elements that are in BOTH sets: A \cap B = \{ x \; | \; x \mbox{ is in } A \mbox{ and } x \mbox{ is in } B\}.
The union of A and B contains every element that occurs in AT LEAST ONE of the sets: A \cup B = \{ x \; | \; x \mbox{ is in } A \mbox{ or } x \mbox{ is in } B \mbox{ (or both)}\}.
Said differently, the intersection of two sets is the overlap of the two sets-all the elements which the sets both have in common. The union of two sets consists of the elements in both of the sets, collected together.

example.title: Interval Intersection and Union
example.p: If A = [-5, 3) and B=(1,\infty), then we can find A \cap B and A \cup B graphically.

sidebyside.p: First, sketch the graphs of A and B.
To determine A \cap B, we shade the overlap of the two and obtain A \cap B = (1, 3).
To determine A \cup B, we shade each of A and B along the lower number line and describe the resulting shaded region to see A \cup B = [-5, \infty).

subsection.p: Here are slightly more complicated situations where the set is in two separate pieces.

example.title: More Intervals
example.p: Express the following sets of numbers using interval notation:

sidebyside.p: Region on the Real Number Line

assemblage.title: WeBWorK: Entering Union \cup and Not Equal \neq
assemblage.p:
Type
Upper case U for union \cup.
!= for \neq.

subsection.title: The Cartesian Coordinate Plane
subsection.p: Math became far more intuitive and powerful when people learned toÂ marry the precision of algebra to the visual intuition of geometry. Simply put, we seek to find a way to draw algebraic things. Let's start with the Cartesian Coordinate Plane, named in honor of the 17th century philosopher, mathematician and scientist, Rene Decartes.
Imagine two real number lines crossing at a right angle at 0 as drawn below.

The horizontal number line is usually called the x-axis while the vertical number line is usually called the y-axis. As with the usual number line, we imagine these axes extending off indefinitely in both directions. Having two number lines enables us to locate the positions of points off of the number lines as well as points on the lines themselves.
For example, consider the point P shown below:

To use the numbers on the axes to label this point, imagine dropping a vertical line from the x-axis to P and extending a horizontal line from the y-axis to P. This process is sometimes called projecting the point P to the x- (respectively y-) axis. We then locate the point P using the ordered pair (2,-4). The first number in the ordered pair is the x-coordinate and the second is the y-coordinate. Taken together, the ordered pair (2, -4) gives the position of the point P with respect to the x and y axes.
Notice that the order in the ordered pair is important: if we wish to plot the point (-4, 2), we would move to the left 4 units from the origin and then move upwards 2 units.

The axes divide the plane into four regions called quadrants. They are labeled Q1, Q2, Q3 and Q4 and proceed counterclockwise around the plane as shown in the graph below. Note that point P is in quadrant 4, Q4, and Q is in quadrant 2, Q2.

subsection.title: Mathematical expressions
subsection.p: You should have be able to simplify basic mathematical expressions with variables and know how to solve an equation for a variable. Below are a few examples for your review.

example.title: Evaluate an Expression
example.p: Evaluate 2p + \dfrac{r^2}{3} for p = -1 and r = 4.
Solution: Substitute -1 for p and 4 for r, and simplify: 2(-1) + \frac{4^2}{3} = -2 + \frac{16}{3} = \frac{-6}{3} + \frac{16}{3} = \frac{10}{3}\checkmark

example.title: Simplify an Expression
example.p: Combine like terms: 3(2x+5)-4x.

In this case one may remove the parentheses by multiplying out the expression 3(2x+5) so that the like terms may be combined.
3(2x+5)-4x 3(2x)+3(5)-4x 6x+15-4x (6x-4x)+15 2x+15 \checkmark

example.title: Solve an Equation
example.p: Solve for x: \dfrac{x}{3}+2=\dfrac{x}{4}

There are many ways to start this problem. If you don't like fractions you may "clear" the denominators by multiplying through both sides of the equation by 12. Then proceed to combine the x's on one side.
12\left(\frac{x}{3} + 2\right) & = 12\left(\frac{x}{4}\right) 12\left(\frac{x}{3}\right) + 12(2) & = 3x 4x + 24 &= 3x 4x + 24 - 3x & = 3x-3x x + 24 & = 0 x & = -24\checkmark

example.title: Solve an Equation
example.p: Solve for C: S = C + rC

The equation needs to be rearranged so that C is isolated. This can be done by factoring C out of the right side then dividing by 1+r:
S = C + rC S = C(1 + r) \frac{S}{1+r} = C
Which may be rewritten in the form: C = \dfrac{S}{1+r} \checkmark

subsection.title: Exponent Properties
subsection.p: Problems with exponents may often be simplified using a few basic exponent properties. For now, exponents represent repeated multiplication. We will use this fact to discover the important properties.

historical.title: World View Note
historical.p: The word exponent comes from the Latin expo meaning out of and ponere meaning place. While there is some debate, it seems that the Babylonians living in Iraq were the first to do work with exponents (dating back to the 23rd century BC or earlier!).

example.title: Multiply a^n times a^m using Exponents

subsection.p: The product rule of exponents can be used to simplify many problems. This is shown in the following examples.

example.title: Product Rule of Exponents
Product Rule of Exponents

subsection.p: Next, we consider what happens when we divide with exponents.

example.title: Division with Exponents
Quotient Rule of Exponents
Quotient Rule of Exponents

subsection.p: A third property we will look at will have an exponent problem raised to a second exponent. This is investigated in the following example:

example.title: Powers with Exponents

subsection.p: This property is often combined with two other properties which we will investigate now.

example.title: Powers of Products

subsection.p:
A quicker method to arrive at the solution is to take the exponent, 3, and put it on each factor in parentheses, (ab)^3 = a^3b^3. This is known as the power of a product rule of exponents:
\text{Power of a Product Rule of Exponents: } (ab)^m=a^m b^m
It is important to be careful to only use the power of a product rule with multiplication inside parentheses. This property does NOT work if there is addition or subtraction inside the parentheses.

assemblage.title: WARNING:

subsection.p: Another property that is very similar to the power of a product rule is considered next.

example.title: Powers of Quotients

subsection.p: The power of a power, product and quotient rules are often used together to simplify expressions. This is shown in the following examples:

example.title: Simplify Exponents

assemblage.title: WeBWorK: Entering Multi-digit Exponents
assemblage.p: If your exponent has two or more digits, you must place parentheses around it. Otherwise, WeBWorK only takes the first number after the ^ as the exponent: Type x^(12) for x^{12}.

example.title: Simplify Exponents

subsection.p: An expression such as 5^3 does not mean we multiply 5 by 3, rather we multiply three 5's together, 5 \cdot 5 \cdot 5 = 125. This is shown in the next example.

example.title: Simplify Exponents

subsection.p: Never multiply a base by the exponent. In the previous example we did not put the 3 on the 4 and multipy to get 12, this would have been incorrect. These properties pertain to exponents only, not bases.
In this lesson we have discussed five different exponent properties. These rules are summarized in the following table:

row.cell: Power of a Power Rule of Exponents
Power of a Product Rule of Exponents
Power of a Quotient Rule of Exponents

subsection.p: These five properties are often mixed up in the same problem. Often there is a bit of flexibility as to which property is used first. However, order of operations still applies to a problem. For this reason it is our suggestion to simplify inside any parentheses first, then simplify any exponents (using power rules), and finally simplify any multiplication or division (using product and quotient rules). This is illustrated in the next few examples.

example.title: Simplify Exponents
Simplify Exponents
Simplify Exponents

subsection.p: These problems can quickly become quite involved. Remember to follow order of operations as a guide, simplify inside parenthesis first, then power rules, then product and quotient rules.

subsection.title: Negative Exponents
subsection.p: A few exponent properties deal with exponents that are not positive. The first is considered in the following example, which is worked out two different ways:

example.title: Investigate Zero Power

subsection.p:
This result is an important property known as the Zero Power Rule of Exponents:
\text{Zero Power Rule of Exponents: } a^0=1
Any number (except 0) or expression raised to the zero power will always be 1. This is illustrated in the following example.

example.title: Zero Power Rule of Exponents

subsection.p: Another property we will consider here deals with negative exponents. Again we will solve the following example two ways.

example.title: Negative Exponents

subsection.p:
This example illustrates an important property of exponents.
\text{Negative Power Rule of Exponents: } a^{-n}= \frac{1}{a^n} \text{ if } a \neq 0
It is important to note that a negative exponent does not mean the expression is negative.

example.title: Simplify a Fraction with a Negative Exponent

subsection.p:
In the example above, we simplified the reciprocal of the fraction by using the method for dividing fractions,
\frac{1}{\frac{a}{b}} = 1 \cdot \frac{b}{a} = \frac{b}{a} \amp\amp\amp \text{}
Following is the rule for negative exponents:
We now have the following nine properties of exponents. It is important that we are very familiar with all of them.

historical.title: World View Note
historical.p: Nicolas Chuquet, the French mathematician of the 15th century wrote 12^{1\overline{m}} to indicate 12x^{-1}. This was the first known use of the negative exponent.
